","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MDIA5031","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MDIA5031 - Research in Practice","description":"

Research—the collection, synthesis and analysis of data—forms the basis of sound communications practice in all its forms. Mindful of the crucial place of research in PR, Advertising, Journalism and Communication industries, this course seeks to activate your research skills, including those relevant to campaign planning, strategy and tactics design, and journalistic investigation. The course focuses on both methodologies—i.e. the epistemological foundations of research—and various research methods, from interviews and surveys to observation and visual analysis. Overall, the course aims to equip you with the knowledge and skills necessary to the development of successful research programs that will to better communication results. This course will also expand your perceptions about future industry career paths and will provide a core foundation required for leadership positions in communication industries.

contentlets.description: Research—the collection, synthesis and analysis of data—forms the basis of sound communications practice in all its forms. Mindful of the crucial place of research in PR, Advertising, Journalism and Communication industries, this course seeks to activate your research skills, including those relevant to campaign planning, strategy and tactics design, and journalistic investigation. The course focuses on both methodologies—i.e. the epistemological foundations of research—and various research methods, from interviews and surveys to observation and visual analysis. Overall, the course aims to equip you with the knowledge and skills necessary to the development of successful research programs that will to better communication results. This course will also expand your perceptions about future industry career paths and will provide a core foundation required for leadership positions in communication industries.
contentlets.title: Research in Practice

The world can turn on a good speech. When moved by a compelling presentation, a client will invest. Through a great interview, a journalist will draw out the truth. Performative communication skills such as these are central to public relations, advertising, and journalism. This course will introduce you to the world of persuasive public speaking, storytelling, interviewing, and presenting. With a focus on spoken communication—including the art of writing and delivering compelling presentations, pitches, and speeches—you will also engage with the deep-seated theory that underpins the art of persuasive oral communication; theory that has been explored and championed for thousands of years.

This course will introduce you to the world of persuasive public speaking, storytelling, interviewing, and presenting. With a focus on spoken communication—including the art of writing and delivering compelling presentations, pitches, and speeches—you will also engage with the deep-seated theory that underpins the art of persuasive oral communication; theory that has been explored and championed for thousands of years.

In recent decades the world has seen the role of government shrink dramatically. This has left a huge hole in the provision of social services; a gap filled by a rapidly growing not-for-profit sector. This sector requires a unique brand of communications centred around representing and speaking on behalf of those who often don’t have a public voice. Accordingly, a specific and multifaceted set of communication skills is required. This course will equip you with such a skill set. You will receive the knowledge and tools necessary for the development of nuanced, ethical, and effective communication programs that speak to principles of social equity and inclusion. You will therefore be positioned to strive for policy change in a vast array of arenas from public health, social services and immigration through to foreign relations, climate change and third-world development.

speaking on behalf of others

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MDIA5100 - Industry Internship","description":"

This course offered by the School of the Arts and Media provides you with an opportunity to undertake industry-engaged learning through internship opportunities with relevant industry hosts. Ideally, you will undertake an internship after you have completed a year of full-time study (or equivalent). At the end of the internship you will provide a summative report of your experiences and work examples completed during the internship.


The internship requires a total commitment of 100-150 hours of work with a host organisation and can be taken in first, second or third term, or over the summer period. Internship opportunities are advertised via the FASS_WIL_SAM Internship page: https://moodle.telt.unsw.edu.au/course/view.php?id=33514. Alternatively, you may independently approach a relevant organisation to apply for an internship. Prior to seeking an internship, you may wish to contact UNSW Careers and Employment - https://www.careers.unsw.edu.au/- for help assembling your CV, cover letter, and other components of your application.


For more information, visit https://www.arts.unsw.edu.au/sam/study-us/internships. For any enquiries, please email the WIL Unit at FASS-WIL@unsw.edu.au


To be eligible for this course, you must have a minimum WAM of 65.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"95e13937db315c50eb6b147a3a961949","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Work Evidence","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will present a sample of, reports on, or links to original work undertaken/produced during and for the purposes of the internship. This may be a holistic written document (eg news story, client profile etc) or records of research undertaken to prepare for a document/event/process in the host organization, reporting on tasks undertaken, description of workflow in relation to a larger process, or similar, ie it should provide evidence of practical work undertaken during the placement. This should be a minimum of 250 words but may make up more of the combined total of 1500-2500 words for both assessment components.


Grading will be Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory only and no further feedback will be provided.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"01e13937db315c50eb6b147a3a961940","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"89e13937db315c50eb6b147a3a961945","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"09e13937db315c50eb6b147a3a961936","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will submit a critical reflection which (i) briefly describes the type of media organization they were placed in (in general terms only, without naming) and their role within it; (ii) identifies a relevant role in the organization at or close to entry level and the skills and attributes needed to complete such a role; (iii) addresses how the type of work they have undertaken/produced during their placement contributes to their host organization and/or relevant media industry. In this last component students should explicitly reflect on such factors as the host/industry agenda, challenges and innovations for the host/industry, questions of ethics which may arise in relation to this work, questions of industry standards, industry processes or media forms. Academic reference should be made, using the Harvard system, and a minimum of five separate academic sources used, to support/explain/define the relevant concepts. The reflective analysis as a whole should be a minimum of 500 words but may make up more of the combined total of 1500-2500 word limit for both assessment components.

\n


Grading will be Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory only and no further feedback will be provided.

contentlets.description:
This course offered by the School of the Arts and Media provides you with an opportunity to undertake industry-engaged learning through internship opportunities with relevant industry hosts. Ideally, you will undertake an internship after you have completed a year of full-time study (or equivalent). At the end of the internship you will provide a summative report of your experiences and work examples completed during the internship.

The internship requires a total commitment of 100-150 hours of work with a host organisation and can be taken in first, second or third term, or over the summer period. Internship opportunities are advertised via the FASS_WIL_SAM Internship page: https://moodle.telt.unsw.edu.au/course/view.php?id=33514. Alternatively, you may independently approach a relevant organisation to apply for an internship. Prior to seeking an internship, you may wish to contact UNSW Careers and Employment - https://www.careers.unsw.edu.au/- for help assembling your CV, cover letter, and other components of your application.

For more information, visit https://www.arts.unsw.edu.au/sam/study-us/internships. For any enquiries, please email the WIL Unit at FASS-WIL@unsw.edu.au

To be eligible for this course, you must have a minimum WAM of 65.
contentlets.title: Industry Internship
